About this page

  • In this page we review the literature which document the development of Adela’s cfMeDIP-seq Technology. The source of all the information contained therein is public.


1 AI Reports

  • AI reports are produced by claude.ai Opus 4.5 with naive prompts from Francois Collin.

  • The reporting done is intended to provide the information needed to underestand the roots and development of Adela’s cfMeDIP-seq Technology.


1.1 Adela vs GRAIL

  • A fairly comprehensive, high level comparison of the two platforms.

  • This compilation is for background purposes - see the documentation below for comments on technical aspects of some of the studies cited.


1.2 cfMeDIP-seq Protocol, Pipeline and Classifiers

  • We trace the evolution of Adela’s cfMeDIP-seq Protocol, Pipeline and Classifiers

  • The report is a fairly comprehensive, high level description of the assay and algorithm along with a description of enhancements that followed.

    • Study by Study Execution Outline

    Shen et al. (2018) [1]

    • Was the Differentially Methylated Regions (DMRs) status between cancer and controls used for selecting features?

    • CV is to determine the hyper-parameters

    Training:

* 10-fold cross-validation for hyper-parameter tuning
* Nested cross-validation for performance estimation
* Class imbalance handled by:
   - Weighted loss function
   - Or downsampling of majority class
    • class imbalance is not an issue when comparing algorithms based on the same sample set.

    • auROC is not a good summary
      • spec at fixed sens would be better
      • but both would order algorithms similarly.


    1.4.1 Controls, Controls, Controls

    • Spike-In Controls - Wilson et al. (2022) [2]

      • How are the Synthetic Spike-In Controls used to reduce unwanted variability?

      • Spike-ins may not be affected by some important sources of variability, but they can only contribute adjustments for variability it is subjected to.

      • What else could be done with these?

      • What other controls could be exploited?

        • endogenous controls
        • sample controls


    1.4.2 Before any modeling, fitting, etc.

    • We need to examine the data:
      • are there obvious quality issues?
      • are there less obvious quality issues?
      • visually, how hard of a classification problem do we have?
        • are cancer types distinct?
        • are there outlier points? Is the outlier due to technical reasons?


    1.4.3 elastic net Vs RF


    References

    1.
    Shen, S.Y., Singhania, R., Fehringer, G., Chakravarthy, A., Roehrl, M.H.A., Chadwick, D., Zuzarte, P.C., Borgida, A., Wang, T.T., Li, T., et al. (2018). Sensitive tumour detection and classification using plasma cell-free DNA methylomes. Nature 563, 579–583.
    2.
    Wilson, S.L., Shen, S.Y., Harmon, L., Burgener, J.M., Triche, T.J., Bratman, S.V., De Carvalho, D.D., and Hoffman, M.M. (2022). Sensitive and reproducible cell-free methylome quantification with synthetic spike-in controls. Cell Rep Methods 2, 100294.
